$BTCTitle: Calm, Focus, and the Importance of Holding in Crypto

Investing in proven projects takes a lot of stress away. These projects always tend to recover, which provides peace of mind and confidence. Of course, you might think: it can‚Äôt go lower, but markets can always drop further ‚Äî as we are seeing now.

Unexpected events can always occur, such as interest rate hikes or news that puts the market under pressure. Speculative positions are often hit harder because there is no certainty that they will recover. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so important to maintain a solid core of proven projects in your portfolio and limit speculative positions. This way, you can benefit from potential upside while always building on a strong foundation.

Another essential aspect of crypto investing is staying in the market. Keep staking, building, and strengthening your proven projects, and avoid unnecessary selling. This is the core of crypto investing: patience, discipline, and confidence in your strategy. By doing so, you never have to sell in panic and can steadily work toward long-term success.

$BTC

When Weak Hands Let Go, Structure Begins to Change

CryptoQuant notes that short-term $BTC  holders remain under pressure, with prolonged losses forcing many out of their positions. On the surface, it looks like exhaustion. Underneath, it looks like a transfer.

This phase is familiar. Price stalls, conviction thins, and patience gets tested. Weak hands sell not because the thesis broke, but because time did. That supply doesn‚Äôt disappear it quietly shifts to holders with a longer horizon and stronger conviction.

Markets rarely turn when sentiment is comfortable. They reset when participation narrows and ownership consolidates. This ‚Äúcleansing‚Äù phase isn‚Äôt loud, but it‚Äôs structural.

The question now isn‚Äôt about today‚Äôs price action it‚Äôs about who‚Äôs still holding when the pressure finally fades.

So ask yourself: is this just another painful pause, or the quiet moment when ownership changes hands before the next move?

$BTC Many people are asking the same question again and again:
Why does the crypto market consistently start falling as soon as the U.S. trading session opens?


In my view, this is not a coincidence anymore. Real control over crypto market liquidity is now concentrated in the United States. The largest funds, ETF issuers, institutional players, and capital flows are based there. A small number of major players effectively dictate market direction ‚Äî primarily through Bitcoin.


The key point is this: the crypto market we used to know no longer exists.
In the past, price action was driven largely by crowd psychology ‚Äî fear, greed, and retail sentiment. That model is gone.
Today‚Äôs market is dominated by algorithms, institutional capital, and centralized liquidity management.


Altcoins make this especially clear. With very few exceptions, they no longer move independently.
When Bitcoin rises, altcoins rise only marginally.
When Bitcoin falls, altcoins collapse much harder and are used as the primary source of liquidations.
They behave less like independent assets and more like leveraged derivatives of BTC.


In reality, the current crypto market increasingly resembles a single centralized system controlled by a handful of multi-billion-dollar entities. And despite this concentration of power, there is virtually no effective oversight. Everything is justified under the banner of a ‚Äúfree market‚Äù ‚Äî even though that free market effectively ended with the launch of spot Bitcoin ETFs in 2024.


ETFs were a turning point. They brought institutional money into crypto, but at the same time destroyed equal conditions for retail traders. Retail is no longer trading against other people ‚Äî it is trading against funds, algorithms, and machines with virtually unlimited liquidity.


This is why traditional market cycles feel broken today.
It‚Äôs not that the cycles failed ‚Äî it‚Äôs that the market itself has fundamentally changed.

A lot of people are asking one question right now:
What comes first 77k or 150k?
Instead of guessing, let‚Äôs read the chart properly.
On the higher timeframe, $BTC is repeating a familiar pattern. Every major move up was followed by a deep pullback into strong demand before the next expansion...
The recent rejection near the top shows the same behavior again price pushed into resistance and sellers stepped in immediately.
Right now, BTC is sitting below a major resistance zone. Until that level is reclaimed with strength, upside remains limited. The structure still shows lower highs, which means the market is not ready to fully turn bullish yet.
On the downside, there is a clear demand area below. If price loses the current support and closes cleanly below it, liquidity opens toward the lower range around the mid-to-high 70k area. That would be a normal pullback in a larger cycle, not the end of Bitcoin.
For a bullish continuation, the condition is simple: BTC must reclaim the previous high area and hold it with volume. Without that, calling 150k is just hope, not analysis.
So what‚Äôs the smart move?
This is not a clean long zone because we are under resistance.
This is not a clean short zone because we are near demand.
The best position right now is patience.
Bottom line Structure is still corrective
Both scenarios are possible
Confirmation matters more than predictions
Either BTC pulls back first to build a stronger base‚Ä¶
Or it reclaims resistance and opens the path higher.
Until the chart decides, this is a wait-and-watch zone.
Logic first. Emotions last.

Such a sharp outflow signals a clear shift in short-term market sentiment. It likely reflects a mix of profit-taking, risk-off positioning, and macro uncertainty, rather than a fundamental rejection of Bitcoin itself.

The key question now is whether this move represents a temporary reset or the start of a sustained de-risking phase by institutional players. 

Watching follow-through in ETF flows over the next few sessions will be critical.

Why #Bitcoin  Is Declining Today: The Real Catalyst Behind the Move  Bitcoin‚Äôs recent pullback is not random, nor is it driven by weakening demand. The primary catalyst is a supply-side shock originating from China, and the timing of this development is critical.  What Triggered the Decline?  Chinese authorities have once again tightened restrictions on domestic Bitcoin mining operations. In December, enforcement intensified in regions with high mining concentration. Estimates suggest that approximately 400,000 mining units were shut down within a short period, creating an immediate disruption to the Bitcoin network.  What the Data Is Showing  The impact is already visible on-chain. Bitcoin‚Äôs network #hashrate  has declined by roughly 8%, reflecting the sudden loss of computing power as miners disconnected from the network.   Why Miner Shutdowns Affect Price? When miners are abruptly forced offline, mining revenue drops instantly, however, operational costs such as electricity, logistics, and relocation still need to be covered. So some miners sell Bitcoin to generate liquidity, increasing short-term uncertainty across the #MARKET . This sequence creates real selling pressure. Importantly, this move does not reflect a breakdown in Bitcoin‚Äôs fundamentals, as the pressure is rooted in policy decisions and is not market weakness.  Bitcoin has experienced similar events in the past. Once network difficulty adjusts, mining activity redistributes geographically. The network, hence, stabilizes and continues operating normally.  What to Expect Going Forward?  In the near term, additional #volatility  is likely as the network adjusts and miners either relocate or resume operations elsewhere. However, from a long-term perspective, this event has minimal impact on Bitcoin‚Äôs trajectory.  This is a short-term supply shock.. Once the adjustment phase passes, the market typically rebalances and $BTC  moves forward.

Short-term $BTC  holders are selling at a loss.     That is a symptom of market stress, not a statement about long-term conviction.   An STH SOPR below 1 typically emerges after sharp, liquidation-driven moves, when recent buyers are forced to exit at unfavorable prices.   This reflects short-term positioning being unwound, not strategic selling by long-term holders. Historically, this phase is part of the market‚Äôs internal reset. Weak hands are cleared, leverage is reduced, and selling pressure gradually compresses.     On its own, SOPR below 1 does not define a top or a bottom.     What matters is whether loss realization slows, allowing price to stabilize and structure to rebuild.     Volatility clears excess. Sustainable trends form only after that process completes.
